posts.post_caption:
The pharmacist gets the thank you.
The patient remembers the counter staff.

The dispenser?

They're in the back. Picking. Checking. Labelling. Reconciling. Filing. Scanning. Answering the phone while doing all of it.

Pharmacy technicians don't just support the pharmacist. They are the reason the pharmacist can do anything else.

Today's their day. Make sure they know it.

#PharmacyTechnicianDay #Dispensers #CommunityPharmacy #TitanPMR

posts.idea:
6-slide carousel. The day-after advocacy pivot.

Slide 1: "Yesterday we celebrated. Today let's talk."
Slide 2: 47 hours a week stat.
Slide 3: 90% workload increase.
Slide 4: Funding decrease in real terms.
Slide 5: More services than ever. The contradiction.
Slide 6: The question. Not whether pharmacists are good enough, but whether the system supports them.

This is the one-two punch. Day 1 emotion, Day 2 advocacy. Mirrors the pattern from your best performing months.
posts.post_caption:
Yesterday we celebrated pharmacists.

Today let's talk about what they actually need.

The average community pharmacist works 47 hours a week.
90% say their workload has increased in the last 2 years.
Funding per item has decreased in real terms since 2015.
Yet pharmacy now delivers more clinical services than ever before.

The question isn't whether pharmacists are good enough. It's whether the system supports them enough.

We built Titan because the tools pharmacists were given didn't match the job they were being asked to do.

That hasn't changed. But it should.

#WorldPharmacistsDay #PharmacyFunding #CommunityPharmacy #TitanPMR
posts.name: TITAN_WorldPharmacistsDay_AdvocacyPivot

posts.idea: Video or carousel. The celebration post. Emotional, people-first, no product. Could use customer footage clips if available, or a simple text-on-screen video with real quotes from pharmacists. This is the shareable, community-building post.
posts.post_caption:
1,400+ pharmacies.
Every one of them run by someone who chose this profession.

Not because it was easy. Because it mattered.

Today we're not talking about workflows or automation or batch dispensing.

We're talking about the people.

The pharmacist who stayed late because a patient didn't understand their new medication.
The dispenser who spotted the interaction the GP missed.
The counter staff who calmed down the parent at 5:55pm on a Friday.

World Pharmacists Day isn't a marketing opportunity. It's a reminder that this profession holds communities together.

Thank you. All of you.

ðŸ‘‰ titanpmr.com

#WorldPharmacistsDay #CommunityPharmacy #PharmacyHeroes

Started from zero, chose the right digital partner, built a profitable and thriving business. And actually the community now has a thriving pharmacy that wasn't there before."

posts.post_caption:
Zero items. Brand new pharmacy. No history.

That was Kanav when he bought Winrosh Pharmacy.

Within six months, he'd adopted a completely new way of working. Click to always fill. Digital-first from day one.

Today? Six to seven thousand items. A profitable, thriving business.

And a community that finally has a pharmacy looking after them that wasn't there before.

These are the stories we hear all the time. And we're proud to be part of them.

Sajid Ramzan, Chief Sales Officer

#TitanPMR #PharmacyGrowth #CommunityPharmacy #NewPharmacy

posts.post_caption:
"Am I making money? Am I making profit? Am I servicing my patients correctly?"

Every pharmacy owner has these questions. Most don't have a way to answer them.

Technology in pharmacy has been stagnant for too long. The systems were built for dispensing, not for running a business.

That's changing. With AI, we're giving pharmacies the ability to see exactly what's happening â€” and act on it.

Not guesswork. Not gut feeling. Real answers.

Wahid Muhammad, CTO

#TitanPMR #PharmacyAI #PharmacyBusiness #Technology

Nobody talks about how stock processes make your team feel.

100 totes every morning instead of 10. Laying everything out. Checking. Reconciling. Two hours before you even start dispensing.

Jeet saw it:

"That made staff more anxious. It was just absolute agony."

Stock control isn't glamorous.

But the difference between a team that starts the day calm and a team that starts the day anxious?

That's everything.

#TitanPMR #StockControl #PharmacyTeam

LinkedIn clip. Tanzil on the migration challenge â€” 3,000 ERD items returned to spine, held back on Titan, prescriptions released back onto queue. Titan team were fantastic.
posts.post_caption:
"My biggest concern moving across to Titan was â€” how do we shift that data?"

Tanzil's pharmacy has one of the highest ERD percentages in England. 70%.

A phenomenal amount of data. Patients on repeat. All sat on the old system.

"Unless we're with Titan, we can't start to use the benefits without moving across. That was the first hurdle."

The result?

"3,000 items. Returned back onto the spine. Pulled them back onto Titan. We've now got that on the queue."

Done.

#TitanPMR #ERD #PharmacyMigration

A cash flow tip from a pharmacy running 40,000 items a month.

Jeet orders bulk lines every two weeks. Enough stock to last four.

"If it's the 25th of the month â€” wait for five days before you order. You've already got two weeks worth of stock. Hang fire. Your cash flow is back to normal."

No software pitch. No feature list.

Just a pharmacist sharing what works.

Stock control isn't just about efficiency. It's about cash flow, confidence, and control.

#TitanPMR #PharmacyBusiness #CashFlow

ðŸ“Ž TRANSCRIPT: Sunil - Not About Cutting People â€” It Leads to Growth_otter_ai.txt

LinkedIn clip. Sunil explains this isn't about cutting people â€” natural wastage creates a plateau, then leads to growth and eventually more staffing at scale.
posts.post_caption:
"This is not about just cutting out people."

Sunil runs 15 pharmacies. He's seen the efficiency gains first-hand.

But here's what actually happens:

"You get the natural wastage first when you change over a system. You can have those conversations with your team. You get a nice plateau."

"But that also then leads to growth. Which will increase staffing later."

"It means you're a much larger business everywhere. Doing more services. Doing all of those things."

Efficiency isn't the end.

It's the beginning.

#TitanPMR #PharmacyGrowth #PharmacyLeadership
posts.name: TITAN_HOD_NotCuttingPeople_LI

posts.post_caption:
No headline stat. No transformation claim.

Just honesty.

Riddhesh is rolling Titan across 16 pharmacies. One site has been live for two months. The rest? Last two weeks.

posts.idea:
5-slide carousel â€” Batch Flow theme

Slide 1: "BATCH VS CHAOS" â€” Split visual: organised batch picking vs cluttered baskets

Slide 2: "THE TRADITIONAL WAY" â€” Pick one script at a time, walk shelves repeatedly, mental load increases, speed costs accuracy

Slide 3: "THE BATCH FLOW WAY" â€” Pick one product for many patients, one shelf run, redistribute with barcode scanning, scale without sacrificing safety

Slide 4: Key stat: "Batch Flow pharmacies process 2-3x the volume with the same team."

Slide 5: CTA â€” "Chaos doesn't scale. Systems do." Titan PMR logo. titanpmr.com
posts.post_caption:
Two ways to dispense 300 items.

The traditional way:
Pick one script at a time.
Walk the shelves 300 times.
Hope nothing goes wrong.

The Batch Flow way:
Pick Metformin for all 47 patients at once.
One shelf run.
Redistribute with barcode scanning.

Batch Flow pharmacies process 2-3x the volume with the same team.

Chaos doesn't scale. Systems do.

ðŸ‘‰ titanpmr.com

#TitanPMR #BatchFlow #PharmacyEfficiency

3,000 items. Returned to the spine. Pulled back onto Titan.

"We've now got that on the queue."

The migration everyone said would be a nightmare. Done.

Quote card â€” single image

Top half â€” the before:
"Ordering 2 inhalers, 5x a week"
(in muted #8b949e text, smaller)

Bottom half â€” the after, large and bold:
"25 inhalers. Once a fortnight. Bang gone."

Divider line between the two in blue (#3498db).

Attribution:
Jeet
Hub & Spoke Operator

Titan PMR logo: Bottom right.

Overall feel: Split comparison. Before is muted and small. After is bold and bright. The visual weight tells the story.
posts.post_caption:
Same inhaler. Ordered five times a week.

Two inhalers each time. Unpacked five mornings running. Laid out across the bench. Booked in separately.

Jeet changed one thing.

"25 inhalers gone in, booked in, and then it will just automatically reorder when we've reached our threshold."

"Staff don't have to lay out 25 different items. They're only laying out one item, 25 of them. Bang gone."

Once a fortnight instead of five times a week.

Stock control isn't glamorous. But the time it gives back is.

#TitanPMR #StockControl #PharmacyEfficiency
posts.name: TITAN_BangGone_Jeet

posts.idea:
5-slide carousel. Ramadan as a pharmacy operations challenge, not just a cultural moment.

Slide 1: Bold hook. "Your patients' medication routines just changed overnight."
Slide 2: What Ramadan means for dosing. Twice-daily meds, insulin timing, skipped doses.
Slide 3: The collection pattern shift. Surge after Iftar, quieter mornings.
Slide 4: What good looks like. Proactive flagging, patient notes, adjusted workflows.
Slide 5: CTA. If your system can't flag this, that's a gap.

Tone: Educational, not preachy. Teach the principle (proactive care during routine disruptions), let Titan be the example.
posts.post_caption:
Your patients' medication routines just changed overnight.

Ramadan means no food or water between dawn and sunset. For 30 days.

That affects:
â†’ Twice-daily medications now need compressing into a shorter window
â†’ Diabetic patients adjusting insulin timing
â†’ Patients skipping doses rather than breaking their fast
â†’ Evening collections surging after Iftar

The pharmacies handling this well aren't guessing. They're using patient notes, flagging at-risk patients proactively, and adjusting their workflow around collection patterns.

This isn't a cultural awareness post. It's a clinical operations one.

If your system can't flag patients who might need a medication review during Ramadan, that's a gap worth closing.

ðŸ‘‰ titanpmr.com

#Ramadan #PharmacyFirst #MedicationSafety #CommunityPharmacy #TitanPMR
posts.name: TITAN_RamadanMedicationTiming

posts.idea:
Rahul Titanverse Transformation â€” Longform Video, 2-3 minutes

---
EDITOR REFERENCE â€” FULL STRUCTURE WITH TIMESTAMPS:

0:00â€“0:15 HOOK
Timestamp 9:09â€“9:15
"Honestly, I can't believe that AI transcription wasn't a thing in pharmacy before."
(Clean hook take, straight to camera. Rehearsed delivery.)

0:15â€“0:45 THE BEFORE â€” ProScript & the old world
Timestamp 1:53â€“2:56
"We got two pharmacies. We were using ProScript... ProScript is quite archaic. It requires you printing off a batch of prescriptions, loads of labels, but it just slowed your whole process down. Baskets were everywhere. Pharmacists had to be actively involved in checking, and it meant that pharmacists didn't have enough time to do the majority of their NHS services, or even start to think about private services."

Also weave in (6:13â€“7:07):
"Writing notes would have been on scraps of paper... you're either typing something, not looking at the patient, or you're scribbling things down... note taking was, in fairness, pretty poor."

0:45â€“1:30 THE SHIFT â€” Titanverse changes everything
Timestamp 9:15â€“9:38 (continuation of hook):
"As soon as we were aware that something had existed in a PMR system, it meant that we could create a safe system. Didn't have to think about using another software, copying and pasting or uploading it elsewhere. It was all in one software."

Timestamp 11:36â€“12:37:
"What we didn't realize with Titanverse was how everything was under one roof. We could send a message to a patient to confirm their appointment... questionnaires were built into it... it meant that we could create a far more streamlined service... Previously we might have thought we could only do five consultations in an hour, and now we can do more."

Timestamp 12:37â€“13:10:
"Titanverse is a game changer. Having something linked to your PMR means you don't have to have multiple tabs open. You have it all under one system. And the fact that it's web based, if I'm in one branch I can access the information for a patient at my other branch."

1:30â€“2:00 THE PROOF â€” How it works day to day
Timestamp 13:24â€“14:29:
Rahul walks through the actual consultation flow: pre-consult questionnaires sent via SMS, clinician reviews before appointment, AI transcription runs during consult, summary generated, full transcript stored, vitals recorded, prescription sent to Titan for dispensing.

Timestamp 19:45â€“20:15:
"Multiple hours a day... we've been able to probably double the amount of consultations that we're doing. The standard of our notes is completely improved."

Timestamp 21:13â€“21:50:
"We've seen that we can now offer twice as many consults, and that's kind of proof in what we're doing."

2:00â€“2:30 THE INDUSTRY VIEW â€” Why this matters now
Timestamp 24:02â€“24:52:
"Long gone are the days that pharmacies should be regarded as just dispensing outlets... funding is completely pulling the rug underneath pharmacies... now thinking about offering private services but high standard and high quality of care... we now use systems like Titan and Titanverse to deliver this in a digital age where patients' expectations are at the highest."

Timestamp 28:37â€“29:22:

posts.idea:
7-slide carousel â€” ROMANTIC MOVIE POSTER PARODIES

CONCEPT: Each slide is a fake romantic movie poster, parodying a famous romance film with pharmacy/AI taglines. Bold cinematic typography, warm golden/rose colour grade throughout. Illustrated silhouette figures or stylised pharmacy scenes â€” NOT actual movie stills. Consistent layout across all slides: movie title top, tagline centre/bottom, subtle romantic poster framing (lens flare, dramatic lighting, etc.)

Slide 1: HOOK â€” Generic rom-com poster style
Title: "Me & AI: A Pharmacy Love Story"
Tagline: "This Valentine's Dayâ€¦ one pharmacist found the one."
Visual: Silhouette of pharmacist gazing at a glowing screen. Warm golden tones, cinematic lens flare.

Slide 2: "The Notebook" parody
Title: "The Logbook"
Tagline: "She checked every script by hand. Until AI saidâ€¦ I'll do it."
Visual: Two silhouettes in dramatic embrace pose â€” one holding a prescription bag. Rain optional.

Slide 3: "Titanic" parody
Title: "Titan-ic"
Tagline: "I'll never let goâ€¦ of your repeat prescriptions."
Visual: Iconic bow-of-the-ship pose but with pharmacy props. Could be a pharmacist with arms spread in front of a glowing Titan screen.

Slide 4: "Crazy, Stupid, Love" parody
Title: "Crazy, Stupid, Workflow"
Tagline: "You had me at 'batch complete'."
Visual: Two figures across a pharmacy counter, romantic tension. One leaning on the counter, the other mid-dispensing.

Slide 5: "10 Things I Hate About You" parody
Title: "10 Things I Hate About My Old PMR"
Tagline: "Paper trails. Chasing. Late finishes. But then I met Titan."
Visual: Pharmacist tearing up a paper prescription list, confetti-style. Dramatic backlight.

Slide 6: "Love Actually" parody
Title: "Cleared Actually"
Tagline: "Friday 5pm. No baskets. No backlog. It's actually happening."
Visual: Pharmacist walking out the door into golden sunset light. Coat on. Bag packed. Pure freedom energy.

Slide 7: END CARD â€” "THE REVIEWS ARE IN" â­â­â­â­â­
Styled like movie critic review quotes / Rotten Tomatoes style.
Warm cinematic background continues. Three real customer quotes styled as movie reviews with star ratings and first names:

â­â­â­â­â­ â€” "Thanks to Titan PMR, I'm probably still in community pharmacy. Otherwise I would have left a long time ago." â€” Prab

â­â­â­â­â­ â€” "Since the time we've had Titan, I think I've managed to become a dad as well." â€” Jeet

â­â­â­â­â­ â€” "It's like a second pair of eyes." â€” Malia

Layout: Stack the three quotes vertically like pull-quote review cards. Each quote in italics with the customer name right-aligned beneath. Star ratings above each quote. Titan PMR logo + titanpmr.com at the bottom.

Optional: Add a "NOW SHOWING AT A PHARMACY NEAR YOU" line above the quotes to keep the movie theme alive.

DESIGN NOTES:
- Consistent warm golden/rose colour grade across all slides
- Bold cinematic serif typography for titles (think movie poster fonts)
- Taglines in lighter weight beneath
- Illustrated/silhouette style â€” NOT photographic, NOT stock photos
- Each slide must work as a standalone image if shared individually
- Keep text readable at mobile size
- Titan PMR logo subtle on slides 1-6, prominent on slide 7
- Slide 7 review quotes should feel like genuine movie critic pull-quotes â€” use quotation marks, italic text, and clean spacing

TONE: Funny, warm, self-aware. Every joke is a real Titan AI benefit in disguise. Product education wrapped in entertainment. Final slide grounds the humour in real customer proof.

posts.idea:
ANIMATED MATRIX â€” Semrush-inspired grid format (see reference screenshots)

Single looping animation that cycles through three states. As the active tab changes, the corresponding tiles highlight in teal.

---

LAYOUT (consistent throughout):
- Header: large text â€” "One service. Five services. Full clinical model."
- Subheader: "Same platform. Different starting points."
- Three tabs across top: [Single Service] | [Multi-Service] | [Full Clinical Model]
- Grid of capability tiles below (4 columns x 4 rows):
  Row 1: Booking | Consultations | AI Scribe | Payments
  Row 2: NMS Workflow | Follow-Ups | Compliance | Reporting
  Row 3: Prescribing | Travel Health | Central Control | PharmAppy Integration
  Row 4: Staff Management | Patient Comms | Clinical Pathways | Multi-Site View
- Titanverse logo bottom right, titanverse.co.uk bottom left

---

STATE 1: "Single Service" tab active (teal)
Highlighted tiles: Booking, Consultations, NMS Workflow, Payments
All other tiles: dark grey (#2a2a3a), white text

STATE 2: "Multi-Service" tab active (teal)
Highlighted tiles: Booking, Consultations, AI Scribe, Payments, NMS Workflow, Follow-Ups, Compliance, Reporting, Travel Health, Clinical Pathways
All other tiles: dark grey

STATE 3: "Full Clinical Model" tab active (teal)
ALL 16 tiles highlighted in teal
Subtext appears at bottom: "One platform. Whatever you need. Whenever you're ready."

---

ANIMATION NOTES:
- Loop: State 1 â†’ State 2 â†’ State 3 â†’ pause â†’ restart
- Each state holds for ~2-3 seconds
- Tiles transition smoothly (fade or colour shift, not instant snap)
- Tab indicator shifts cleanly between states
- Total loop: ~8-10 seconds

---

DESIGN NOTES:
- Dark background (#0d0d1a or similar)
- Teal highlight: Titanverse brand teal
- Grey tiles: #2a2a3a with white text
- Clean, modern grid â€” rounded corners on tiles
- Reference: Semrush SEO/AEO matrix post (screenshots provided)
- Keep tiles compact â€” 2-3 words max per tile
- No icons needed, text-only tiles work best for this format

posts.idea:
Carousel Script (7 slides):
SLIDE 1 (Hook):

Â£158 MILLION CLAWBACK

Announced Dec 23rd.
Two days before Christmas.
Quietly slipped out.

Here's what you need to know.
SLIDE 2 (What is clawback?):

WHAT IS CLAWBACK?

The CPCF sets an "allowed profit envelope" for pharmacy.

If the sector's profit exceeds this level, the government claws it back the following year.

Sounds fair?

Keep reading.
SLIDE 3 (The unfair bit):

HERE'S THE CATCH

Clawback is calculated on the WHOLE INDUSTRY.

Not individual pharmacies.

If Boots makes excess profit, your pharmacy pays too.

Even if you're dispensing at a loss.
SLIDE 4 (The numbers):

THE REALITY

- Â£16.8m clawed back per quarter
- Starting January 2026
- Applied to Category M and A drugs
- No individual assessment
- No appeals process
SLIDE 5 (The context):

THE BIGGER PICTURE

- 63% of pharmacies at risk of closure
- 248 closed in 2024 alone
- <10,000 remain in England
- 60% of owners took no salary in 2024
- Â£2.6bn funding gap

And now: clawback.
SLIDE 6 (The quote):

"Pharmacies cannot plan, cannot invest, and are forced to dispense NHS medicines, day after day, often at a loss."

â€“ Olivier Picard, NPA Chair
SLIDE 7 (CTA):

WHAT CAN YOU DO?

1. Understand your exposure
2. Track affected drug categories
3. Make the opaque visible

Titan can help.

titanpmr.com
Visual Brief:
â€¢ Bold, stark design
â€¢ Use red/warning colour accents
â€¢ Large numbers on each slide
â€¢ Clean, impactful typography
â€¢ NPA quote on dedicated slide
â€¢ Titan positioning subtle - focused on industry advocacy first
Notes:
â€¢ This is "editorial/oracle" positioning - Titan being the voice of pharmacy
â€¢ Pairs anger/injustice with practical help (reporting)
â€¢ Follows the Mounjaro pricing post formula (timely + affects wallets + emotional)
â€¢ Can link to a future "how Titan helps with clawback tracking" follow-up post

posts.post_caption:
Technician supervision has already begun in UK pharmacy.

This legal change is a good thing because it reflects what already happens in most community pharmacies.

Pharmacists check the prescription, authorise it and seal the medication.

When the patient arrives, the handout is often completed by a trained member of the pharmacy team.

The new law simply formalises this workflow.

Titan supports this transition.
Titanâ€™s workflow shows who checked the item and when it was authorised.
Titan Mobile adds clinical continuity by prompting the team with the pharmacistâ€™s notes at handout, such as NMS reminders or key counselling points.

This gives pharmacies a safe, structured way to delegate handout while keeping the pharmacistâ€™s clinical guidance in the process.

hashtag#CommunityPharmacy hashtag#TechnicianSupervision hashtag#PharmacyPractice hashtag#TitanPMR

posts.post_caption:
Technician supervision has already begun in UK pharmacy.

This legal change is a good thing because it reflects what already happens in most community pharmacies.

Pharmacists check the prescription, authorise it and seal the medication.

When the patient arrives, the handout is often completed by a trained member of the pharmacy team.

The new law simply formalises this workflow.

Titan supports this transition.
Titanâ€™s workflow shows who checked the item and when it was authorised.
Titan Mobile adds clinical continuity by prompting the team with the pharmacistâ€™s notes at handout, such as NMS reminders or key counselling points.

This gives pharmacies a safe, structured way to delegate handout while keeping the pharmacistâ€™s clinical guidance in the process.

hashtag#CommunityPharmacy hashtag#TechnicianSupervision hashtag#PharmacyPractice hashtag#TitanPMR

posts.post_caption:
Bulk nomination is undermining patient choice.

And it has created a completely unfair playing field.

Some PMR systems allow pharmacies to switch patients back in bulk, without consent and without a conversation. Patients have no idea their nomination has changed behind their backs.

Pharmacies who refuse to do this lose business.
Pharmacies who do it gain business.
That isnâ€™t fair competition. Itâ€™s a broken system.

Bulk switching goes directly against patient choice.
And it punishes the pharmacies who try to do the right thing.

There are only two legitimate scenarios for a bulk nomination change:
â€¢ When a pharmacy is sold
â€¢ When two pharmacies merge
And even then, the NHS manages the change â€” not the PMR system.

Everywhere else, nomination should stay where it belongs:
with the patient.

If you agree this needs to stop, take a stand with us.

posts.post_caption:
The patient comes first. 

Stop nomination ping-pong.

The NHS Electronic Prescription Service is one of the most advanced prescribing systems in the world. It works because patient nomination is meant to be clear, deliberate, and respected.

But there is a flaw. Some systems can automatically reverse a patientâ€™s pharmacy nomination, without the patient knowing.

When that happens, prescriptions can bounce between pharmacies. Patients lose clarity about where their medicines are. Trust takes the hit first. And pharmacies playing fair are put at a disadvantage.

At scale, this creates risk for EPS itself. It was not designed for businesses to fight over nominations through automation.

We were asked to build this functionality. We refused. Not because we couldnâ€™t, but because it breaches our values around patient safety, professional standards, and fair competition.

Patient choice must mean something.

ðŸ‘‰ Sign the petition: bit.ly/3YH8boA

#PatientChoice #EPS #NHSPharmacy #PharmacyEthics #PatientCare #CommunityPharmacy

posts.post_caption:
Independent Prescribing should be the future.

So why will it struggle in 2026?

Every branch is training more IPs. Every policy document points to a more clinical role. But in reality, most pharmacists still start their day the same way they did ten years ago: clearing repeats, chasing stock and firefighting the bench.

Pharmacy First showed the demand is there.
What is missing is capacity.

Training more prescribers cannot overcome a workflow that gives them no time to prescribe.

Until the operational model changes, IP cannot scale.
The bottleneck is not skill. It is time.

posts.post_caption:
Spot the difference. 

The GTIN doesnâ€™t.

Right now in UK pharmacy, different medicines are arriving with the same GTIN barcode or a GTIN that does not match the product inside.

When that happens, the scanner passes the wrong medicine as correct. Every safety layer collapses.

Pharmacists are forced to slow down, override the check, and carry the risk that should sit with manufacturers and regulators.

This is not a workflow problem. It is a patient safety problem.

The fix is simple:
â€¢ Make accurate GTIN barcodes mandatory
â€¢ Treat incorrect GTINs as labelling errors
â€¢ Protect the final safety check that keeps patients safe

If you work in pharmacy, please add your name.
This is a small action that protects every dispenser in the country.

ðŸ‘‰ Sign the petition: bit.ly/3XNxapM

#EveryPackCounts #PharmacySafety #GTIN #CommunityPharmacy #TitanPMR

â€¢ Law in force: 1 Oct 2025

posts.post_caption:
Sure, Teslas can drive themselves.

But pharmacists cannot swap a pill.

That is where we are in 2025.

Patients are waiting up to three weeks for essential medicines.
Not because shelves are empty.
But because pharmacists are legally blocked from substituting.

The result:
ðŸ‘‰ Patients left untreated
ðŸ‘‰ Surgeries drowning in calls
ðŸ‘‰ Pharmacies stuck in the firing line

The absurdity is obvious.
We trust machines to steer cars through traffic.
But not pharmacists to use their training when a drug is out of stock.

The CCA and others are pushing for substitution rights, deprescribing roles and more front line flexibility. The NHS 10 Year Plan points the same way.

The question is not whether pharmacy is ready.
It is whether the rules will catch up.

#pharmacy #NHS #shortages #patientcare #TitanPMR

posts.post_caption:
Sunshine. Laughter. Basically a school sports day.

Titan BBQ 25 had it all.

Once a year, we get the whole Titan crew together for BBQ 25. A day to swap the laptops for laughter, the deadlines for a bit of good-natured rivalry, and remember what it is like to be properly outside.

ðŸ¥¥ Coconut shy
âš½ Football speed tests
ðŸ’ª Tug of war
ðŸƒ Sack races (with some questionable technique)
ðŸ” And food worth queueing twice for

It had all the magic of being back on the school field, just with fewer grazed knees and much better catering.

Thank you to every single one of you for bringing the energy, the humour and the team spirit that made BBQ 25 what it was. You turned it into more than just a day out, you made it a day to remember.

Here is to BBQ 26. Same time next year. Same team.

#TitanBBQ25 #TeamTitan #SummerCelebration

People double-check because the system lets work move forward without confirmation.

It shows up as cognitive load.

Stable dispensing isnâ€™t about asking people to focus harder.

posts.post_caption:
Bulk nomination is undermining patient choice.

And it has created a completely unfair playing field.

Some PMR systems allow pharmacies to switch patients back in bulk, without consent and without a conversation. Patients have no idea their nomination has changed behind their backs.

Pharmacies who refuse to do this lose business.
Pharmacies who do it gain business.
That isnâ€™t fair competition. Itâ€™s a broken system.

Bulk switching goes directly against patient choice.
And it punishes the pharmacies who try to do the right thing.

There are only two legitimate scenarios for a bulk nomination change:
â€¢ When a pharmacy is sold
â€¢ When two pharmacies merge
And even then, the NHS manages the change â€” not the PMR system.

Everywhere else, nomination should stay where it belongs:
with the patient.

If you agree this needs to stop, take a stand with us.

ðŸ‘‰ Sign the petition: bit.ly/3YH8boA

posts.post_caption:
Spot the difference. 

The GTIN doesnâ€™t.

Right now in UK pharmacy, different medicines are arriving with the same GTIN barcode or a GTIN that does not match the product inside.

When that happens, the scanner passes the wrong medicine as correct. Every safety layer collapses.

Pharmacists are forced to slow down, override the check, and carry the risk that should sit with manufacturers and regulators.

This is not a workflow problem. It is a patient safety problem.

The fix is simple:
â€¢ Make accurate GTIN barcodes mandatory
â€¢ Treat incorrect GTINs as labelling errors
â€¢ Protect the final safety check that keeps patients safe

If you work in pharmacy, please add your name.
This is a small action that protects every dispenser in the country.

ðŸ‘‰ Sign the petition: bit.ly/3XNxapM

#EveryPackCounts #PharmacySafety #GTIN #CommunityPharmacy #TitanPMR

posts.idea:
SLIDE 1 â€” HOOK

Manual checking works.
Until scale makes it unsafe.

â¸»

SLIDE 2 â€” THE BEHAVIOUR

Why does manual double-checking exist?

Because verification isnâ€™t enforced at the point of action.
So people compensate.

â¸»

SLIDE 3 â€” THE FAILURE

This works until volume breaks it.

Vigilance degrades faster than workload increases.

â¸»

SLIDE 4 â€” THE COST

The cost lands on cognitive load.

Mental energy goes into catching errors
instead of overseeing care.

â¸»

SLIDE 5 â€” WHAT FAILS FIRST

Dispensing stability breaks first.

When safety depends on human presence,
scale becomes a risk.

â¸»

SLIDE 6 â€” CLOSE

Systems should absorb complexity.
People shouldnâ€™t.
posts.post_caption:
Manual verification feels responsible.
Until it becomes the bottleneck.

People double-check because the system lets work move forward without confirmation.
Thatâ€™s fine at low volume.

At scale, repetition erodes attention.
Safety becomes probabilistic.
And throughput is gated by one human checkpoint.

The cost doesnâ€™t show up as failure straight away.
It shows up as cognitive load.

Stable dispensing isnâ€™t about asking people to focus harder.
Itâ€™s about building systems that donâ€™t rely on focus at all.

posts.idea:
Carousel Script (7 slides):
SLIDE 1 (Hook):

Â£158 MILLION CLAWBACK

Announced Dec 23rd.
Two days before Christmas.
Quietly slipped out.

Here's what you need to know.
SLIDE 2 (What is clawback?):

WHAT IS CLAWBACK?

The CPCF sets an "allowed profit envelope" for pharmacy.

If the sector's profit exceeds this level, the government claws it back the following year.

Sounds fair?

Keep reading.
SLIDE 3 (The unfair bit):

HERE'S THE CATCH

Clawback is calculated on the WHOLE INDUSTRY.

Not individual pharmacies.

If Boots makes excess profit, your pharmacy pays too.

Even if you're dispensing at a loss.
SLIDE 4 (The numbers):

THE REALITY

- Â£16.8m clawed back per quarter
- Starting January 2026
- Applied to Category M and A drugs
- No individual assessment
- No appeals process
SLIDE 5 (The context):

THE BIGGER PICTURE

- 63% of pharmacies at risk of closure
- 248 closed in 2024 alone
- <10,000 remain in England
- 60% of owners took no salary in 2024
- Â£2.6bn funding gap

And now: clawback.
SLIDE 6 (The quote):

"Pharmacies cannot plan, cannot invest, and are forced to dispense NHS medicines, day after day, often at a loss."

â€“ Olivier Picard, NPA Chair
SLIDE 7 (CTA):

WHAT CAN YOU DO?

1. Understand your exposure
2. Track affected drug categories
3. Make the opaque visible

Titan can help.

titanpmr.com
Visual Brief:
â€¢ Bold, stark design
â€¢ Use red/warning colour accents
â€¢ Large numbers on each slide
â€¢ Clean, impactful typography
â€¢ NPA quote on dedicated slide
â€¢ Titan positioning subtle - focused on industry advocacy first
Notes:
â€¢ This is "editorial/oracle" positioning - Titan being the voice of pharmacy
â€¢ Pairs anger/injustice with practical help (reporting)
â€¢ Follows the Mounjaro pricing post formula (timely + affects wallets + emotional)
â€¢ Can link to a future "how Titan helps with clawback tracking" follow-up post

Independent Prescribing should be the future.

So why will it struggle in 2026?

Every branch is training more IPs. Every policy document points to a more clinical role. But in reality, most pharmacists still start their day the same way they did ten years ago: clearing repeats, chasing stock and firefighting the bench.

Pharmacy First showed the demand is there.
What is missing is capacity.

Training more prescribers cannot overcome a workflow that gives them no time to prescribe.

Until the operational model changes, IP cannot scale.
The bottleneck is not skill. It is time.

posts.post_caption:
Sure, Teslas can drive themselves.

But pharmacists cannot swap a pill.

That is where we are in 2025.

Patients are waiting up to three weeks for essential medicines.
Not because shelves are empty.
But because pharmacists are legally blocked from substituting.

The result:
ðŸ‘‰ Patients left untreated
ðŸ‘‰ Surgeries drowning in calls
ðŸ‘‰ Pharmacies stuck in the firing line

The absurdity is obvious.
We trust machines to steer cars through traffic.
But not pharmacists to use their training when a drug is out of stock.

The CCA and others are pushing for substitution rights, deprescribing roles and more front line flexibility. The NHS 10 Year Plan points the same way.

The question is not whether pharmacy is ready.
It is whether the rules will catch up.

#pharmacy #NHS #shortages #patientcare #TitanPMR
posts.name: 3 Weeks No Meds
